group: EGSC - Engineering Graduate Student Council, Columbia University
description: This event will showcase the ongoing research in SEAS departments and highlight the achievements of the EGSC Professional Development Scholars. Labs with with open positions will describe the opportunities available for short- to long-term research assistantships. Masters student interested in research are particularly encouraged to attend! Refreshments will be served.
title: EGSC Research Symposium

group: EGSC - Engineering Graduate Student Council, Columbia University
description: Learn details regarding the upcoming vote on Dec 7 - 8th and openly discuss the impact of unionizing with other graduate students. Share with your friends!!!
title: Town Hall on Unionization

description: Cathy O'Neil discusses her book, Weapons of Math Destruction, and the power of algorithms to destroy lives, increase inequality and threaten democracy.
title: Weapons of Math Destruction

description: Cathy O'Neill discusses her book Weapons of Math Destruction and the potential for algorithms to discriminate and threaten democracy.
title: Cathy O'Neill: Weapons of Math Destruction

description:
Get Your Back Rub On. 
Kick off your reading week right, with free neck and back rubs and a bunch of stressbusting swag! #CUStressbusters #StressbustersinButler
---
Columbia Health makes every effort to accommodate individuals with disabilities. If you require disability accommodations to attend an event sponsored by Columbia Health, or by the University, please contact Disabilities Services at (212) 854-2388 at least 5 days in advance of the event.
title: Stressbusters in Butler

description:
Columbia University's startup accelerator, Almaworks, will be hosting a demo day for its Fall 2016 graduating class. For the past few months, these startups have been hacking, scaling, and hustling to prepare their pitches for this capstone event. This event is open to the public and requires no prior registration.

Come watch some of the top student startups in Columbia pitch to the NYC startup community and then attend the post-pitch dinner session where you will be able to talk with all the teams in the 3rd Almaworks class. Free food and refreshments will be served.

Learn more about Almaworks at www.alma.works and learn more about CORE at www.coreatcu.com.
title: Almaworks Fall 2016 Demo Day
location: Davis Auditorium, CEPSR (1st Floor, 530 West 120th Street)

description:
Want to hear more about what's going on in the Fashion Tech industry? Join us to hear more about technologies such as interactive shopping experiences through video players, fashion genome sequencing, how trends are being tracked and established through data, and more.

Panelists include:
Karoline Gross, Founder & CEO of Smartzer
Shareen Pathak, Editor at Glossy
Cristina Pachon, Co-founder of Genostyle
Deb Li, Head of NY Operations at EDITED
title: The Future of Fashion Tech

description:
Startup Social is a meetup that revolves around building the community of the entrepreneurially-minded members of Columbia University.

Come enjoy some FREE FOOD and chat with students and entrepreneurs from Columbia University and throughout New York. 

If you don't have access to Lerner Hall please fill this form at least a day before the event:
https://coreatcu.wufoo.com/forms/zkqnwl91941cp6/

Interested in pitching an idea to a talented group of students at the start of our next Startup Social? Submit this form:
https://coreatcu.wufoo.com/forms/z14into4185dqp1/
title: CORE Startup Social

description: Come to our mixer to talk to alumni and representatives from different companies about what it's like to be a woman in the workforce. Learn about job opportunities, expand your network, and make new friends over free snacks!
title: Women in the Werkforce

description:
CCSC, SGA, GSSC, and ESC present the annual Tree Lighting Ceremony on Thursday, December 1st at 6PM! Come celebrate Columbia's cherished winter tradition with friends!

We will serve hot chocolate and cider and have amazing Columbia swag starting at 5:30pm. At 6, there will be performances from a cappella groups, special words from your student councils, and of course, the count down for the tree lighting itself!

**Want a chance to perform at Tree Lighting? We invite and encourage all Acappella groups to fill out this form to express interest in auditioning for a spot: https://goo.gl/forms/F6ksyWNAl96hzXn13

**SENIORS! Don't forget to attend the Senior Winter Gala after the ceremonies! More details to come. 

**CC STUDENTS!
Join fellow Columbians in an annual tradition hosted by the Columbia College Alumni Association! Watch as College Walk's trees are lit up, then join friends and College alumni in the Journalism School's World Room for a Winter Celebration! Enjoy food, drinks and musical performances. This event is free for College students.

And finally, shout out to Helen Yu for the wonderful cover photo and poster design! 

We can't wait to see everyone there!
title: CU Tree Lighting Ceremony 2016

description:
'Twas the night before Tree Lighting and there were free beanies!

Come by the Lerner Party Space 9:00 PM on Wednesday for some delicious holiday desserts and treats, a stylin' photobooth, and FREE Columbia College beanies!

Can't wait to see you there, and to join everyone outside on Low Plaza for the CU Tree Lighting Ceremony 2016 on Thursday!
title: Twas the Night Before Tree Lighting

description: Come chill with our BME department's very own Dr. Hess, whose work is concerned with "engineering at the molecular scale, in particular the design of active nanosystems incorporating biomolecular motors, the study of active self-assembly, and the investigation of protein-resistant polymer coatings."  Ask him about anything from his career path to his go-to dinner spots.
title: Fun with Faculty: Dr. Hess!
location: BME Conference Room, 3rd Floor Mudd (Engineering Terrace), Follow the Signs

description: Join your BMES friends and family for some cookie decorating fun! We will decorating sugar cookies and watching a holiday movie! So bring your holiday spirit and ugly holiday sweaters to celebrate the end of the semester!
title: BMES Cookie Making Fun!

description:
Already have a full-time job offer? Considering getting your MBA in the future and want to get a head-start? Even if you're an underclassman just starting to explore the idea of business school, it's never too early to start preparing.

The Columbia Economics Society is hosting an admissions seminar with Chioma Isiadinso, CEO of MBA admissions consulting firm EXPARTUS and former Harvard admissions board member, to help Columbia students discover how to apply successfully to the Harvard 2+2 MBA program. This seminar will also cover other early career admissions options at top schools like Stanford Graduate School of Business and Yale School of Management.

***PLEASE RSVP by clicking "Going" on this event, and use the following link to secure a spot at the event: 
http://www.expartus.com/seminar

The event is FREE to students and will teach applicants how to apply with confidence and when to apply to elite MBA programs to get an edge in the application process. A 1-hour seminar is typically priced at $350.

Here’s what you’ll learn at this seminar: 
• How to assess whether you should apply to the 2+2 program or postpone your application
• Mistakes 2+2 applicants make and how to avoid them
• Who to use for recommenders
• Other early career application programs (Stanford and Yale)
• And much more

We look forward to seeing you there!

-----------------------------------


A note from Chioma Isiadinso: 

I am the CEO of EXPARTUS (www.expartus.com), an admissions consulting and personal branding company that has helped thousands of clients from over 200 countries to gain admission at the world’s best business schools. 

We help our clients discover their personal brand and communicate it effectively through their application, and this unique branding method sets EXPARTUS apart. 

As a former Harvard Business School admissions board member and former director of admissions at Carnegie Mellon University, I have seen firsthand the power of personal branding in helping applicants get admitted to top schools without necessarily being the obvious choice based on their academic and professional credentials. 

Top schools want diversity. They want individuals who are passionate and who will change the world. Applicants who are able to make a strong case that they will impact their world and that they are authentic and engaged individuals will always stand out from their competition. This is what we teach our clients at EXPARTUS. 

After 20 years in the admissions industry I know that personal branding works. I know that authenticity wins. Helping thousands of clients over the nearly 15 years of leading EXPARTUS, with my incredible team of consultants, has proven to me that it’s not about being perfect. It’s not about just having the highest test scores. It’s about self-awareness; helping applicants discover who they are and the impact they want to have in the world. 

In addition to my leadership responsibilities at EXPARTUS, I am an international speaker on the subject of education and admissions and have presented to organizations like the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business (AACSB), JP Morgan, and Bank of America. I am the author of "The Best Business Schools' Admissions Secrets" and provide interviews to the Financial Times, the New York Times, CNBC, and Bloomberg BusinessWeek.com.
title: Early MBA Admissions Secrets- Q&A with ex-HBS Admissions Officer

description: Are you considering majoring in economics? Interested in research, law, finance, venture capitalism, or sustainable development? Join Columbia Economics Society for a discussion with CU upperclassmen pursuing or experienced in these fields to gain a better understanding for the possibilities open to econ majors and learn how to make the most out of Columbia to excel in these areas!
title: So You Want to be an Econ Major?

description:
Come join Culinary Society for our last event of the semester! Members will be cooking and baking delicious comfort foods. It's a great chance to taste good food and take a break from studying!

If you want to cook for the event, please sign up here! https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1YyppHjsQ_Cqu7QIJJcMDizbDDa2MXKenMXHzQSQFN3Q/edit#gid=0
title: CU Culinary Society: Comfort Food Study Break

description: Midterm/Finals Season got you worked up? Can't find a seat in Butler? Study with other FLIP students! We will open our regular g-body space for all FLIP identifying students to study or hang out with each other.
title: Study & Chill w/ FLIP

description:
Throughout the year, the department will host events to discuss a variety of post graduation options. Our second event will focus on full time Research Assistant positions. The session will begin with a brief discussion of the types of full-time RA opportunities and the process through which students obtain such jobs.  All of these positions will require data analysis skills. The main part of the evening will be a tutorial covering common tasks related to data manipulation and analysis using Stata. These examples are inspired by the "Stata tests" that are often used during interview processes for RA jobs. The tasks cover topics such as merging data sets and using macros, loops, string functions, and datetime functions. The tutorial is intended for those who are familiar with the Stata interface and the basic commands (from Intro to Econometrics), but those who have never used Stata are also welcome to attend. Students interested in pursuing graduate work in economics are strongly encouraged to attend. 

FOOD WILL BE PROVIDED.
 
To receive information about our upcoming information sessions, please subscribe to the mailing list, econevents. To subscribe to this list follow the link 
https://lists.columbia.edu/mailman/listinfo/econevents
and simply follow the directions there to subscribe yourself to the list.
title: Economics Dept.: Research Assistant Information Session

description:
Science is not an individual sport—teams are the heart of public health and the backbone of ground-breaking achievements. The 2016-2017 Grand Rounds series brings together collaborators from across the Mailman School's disciplines and portfolios for discussions about how interdisciplinary teams are breaking down silos to to take on issues including obesity, climate change, and racism and violence. 

November's event - titled "A Pipeline Approach to Team Science: From Concepts to Communities" - will feature a discussion with Raygine DiAquoi, Director of the Office of Diversity, Culture, and Inclusion and Assistant Professor of Sociomedical Sciences, and Gina Wingood, Sidney and Helaine Lerner Professor of Public Health in Sociomedical Sciences.

If you're not able to attend in person, this event will be livestreamed here: https://livestream.com/mailman/communities and we encourage you to tweet and follow along the conversation using #TeamScience.
title: Pipeline Approach to Team Science: From Concepts to Communities
